key_points: The Anti-Defamation League (ADL) appealed to Facebook's Oversight Board to address the platform's handling of anti-Semitic content.
ADL accuses Facebook of allowing 'thousands' of instances of Jewish hate to persist despite community standards banning hate speech.
The complaint highlighted seven specific posts that Facebook did not remove, despite ADL's reports and claims they violated Facebook policies.
ADL's vice president of Innovation and Strategy, Adam Neufeld, pointed out that public pages and even worse content on private pages contain anti-Semitic posts.
This marks the first time ADL has appealed to Facebook's Oversight Board regarding content moderation since its launch.
Neufeld emphasized the growing problem of anti-Semitism on Facebook and the platform's inaction contributing to real-world attacks.
Facebook has not addressed questions about why the reported posts were not considered violations of its community guidelines.
Facebook spokesperson stated the company was horrified by the rise in anti-Semitism and has taken steps to ban stereotypes and dangerous organizations.
Facebook faced criticism and a corporate boycott over failing to moderate hate speech but has tightened its moderation policies over the past year.
An ADL analysis found over 17,000 tweets with the phrase "Hitler was right" on Twitter following the Israel-Gaza conflict, showing a wider issue on social media.
spokespersons: Adam Neufeld (Vice President of Innovation and Strategy, ADL)
